bestBHT.bht: True discipleship requires a love for Christ that surpasses all earthly relationships. Jesus does not mean to hate family, but rather emphasizes a sense of alienation from worldly ties. Loving Christ should take precedence over self-preservation. This teaching calls us to let go of our closest relations and even life itself to follow Jesus.

Henry Alford: the hate is the general, not personal, feeling of alienation in the inmost heart
so that this world’s relationships, as belonging to the state things in this world, are not the home and rest of the heart

This addition also shews that the saying was not meant only for those times, in which more perhaps of the disruption of earthly ties was required, but for all time: for his own life is equally dear to every man in every age.
Philip Schaff: The demand is for supreme love to Christ: father, and mother, etc., are placed here as objects which may and often do interfere with this supreme love.
In so far as they do this, they are to be hated, not actively and personally, but generally.
The power to love implies the power to hate. Alford: ‘This hate is not only consistent with, but absolutely necessary to the very highest kind of love.
Archibald T. Robertson: But even so Jesus does not here mean that one must hate his father or mother of necessity or as such, for Matthew 15:4 proves the opposite.
In mentioning 'and wife' Jesus has really made a comment on the excuse given in verse Luke 14:20 (I married a wife and so I am not able to come).
Love for Christ takes precedence 'over even the elemental instinct of self-preservation' (Ragg).
John Gill: Not that proper hatred of any, or all of these, is enjoined by Christ; for this would be contrary to the laws of God, to the first principles of nature, to all humanity, to the light of nature, to reason and divine revelation.
But that these are not to be preferred to Christ, or loved more than he.

Such who would be accounted the disciples of Christ, should be ready to part with their dearest relations and friends, with the greatest enjoyment of life, and with life itself when Christ calls for it; or otherwise they are not worthy to be called his disciples.
John Wesley: If any man come to me, and hate not his father
Comparatively to Christ: yea, so as actually to renounce his field, oxen, wife, all things, and act as if he hated them, when they stand in competition with him.

bhtAttempts.bht: True discipleship requires a deep commitment and love for Christ that surpasses all earthly relationships and attachments. Jesus does not literally mean to hate one's father, mother, wife, or even one's own life. Rather, he emphasizes the need for a general feeling of alienation from worldly ties, recognizing that this world and its relationships are not the ultimate source of fulfillment. Loving Christ should take precedence over even the most instinctual self-preservation. This timeless teaching calls us to be willing to let go of our dearest relations, friends, and even the pleasures and enjoyments of life if necessary, in order to wholeheartedly follow Jesus.

To truly be a disciple of Christ, we must have a deep and unwavering love for Him that transcends all earthly attachments. Jesus does not mean that we should literally hate our family or ourselves, but rather, He teaches us to place our love for Him above all else. This requires recognizing that worldly relationships and possessions do not offer true fulfillment. We must be willing to let go of our closest relationships and even our own lives if necessary, in order to fully devote ourselves to following Jesus.

In Luke 14:26, Jesus calls for a deep commitment to Him that surpasses all earthly bonds. He does not mean that we should literally hate our loved ones, but rather, we are called to prioritize our love for Him above all else. This requires recognizing that worldly relationships and possessions can hinder our devotion to Him. True discipleship necessitates being willing to let go of our closest relationships and even our own lives, if needed, in order to fully follow Jesus.
